# History of FOSS

## In the beginning... {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**Software was free**

- 1950s-1970s: Software bundled with hardware
- Source code shared freely among researchers
- Collaboration was the norm

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/2942/2942156.png){width="200" fig-alt="Collaboration icon"}

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**Then came commercialization**

- Late 1970s-1980s: Software became a product
- Companies realized revenue potential
- Proprietary licenses became standard
- Source code became trade secret

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/3135/3135706.png){width="200" fig-alt="Business revenue icon"}

:::

# Software Licenses

## What are software licenses? {.smaller}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 20px; border-radius: 15px; margin: 15px 0; border: 2px solid #8be9fd; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**A software license is a legal instrument** governing the use, modification, and distribution of software.

:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="65%"}

**Why are they important?**

- Software is protected by **copyright** law by default
- Without a license, you have **no legal right** to use, copy, or modify software
- Licenses grant permissions while setting conditions
- Violating license terms can result in legal action

:::

::: {.column width="35%"}

![](media/laurent.jpg){width="250" fig-alt="Laurent illustration"}

:::

::::

## Two license philosophies {.smaller}

The free software and open source movements led to two main license types:

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; font-size: 0.85em; border: 2px solid #8be9fd; color: #f8f8f2;"}

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;"}
Reciprocal (Copyleft)
:::

**Origin:** Free Software Movement

**Philosophy:** Preserve freedom for all users

**Key Feature:** Derivatives must use same license

**Examples:** GPL, AGPL, MPL

**Goal:** Ensure software remains free

:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; font-size: 0.85em; border: 2px solid #bd93f9; color: #f8f8f2;"}

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 10px;"}
Permissive
:::

**Origin:** Academic institutions, OSI

**Philosophy:** Maximum freedom to developers

**Key Feature:** Minimal restrictions

**Examples:** MIT, BSD, Apache

**Goal:** Enable broad adoption and use

:::

:::

::::

## Reciprocal License Example {.smaller}

**GNU General Public License v2.0**

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #8be9fd; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**Key Features:**

- **Strong copyleft** - Derivatives must be GPL-2
- **Source code disclosure** required upon distribution
- **Same license terms** for all recipients
- **Patent grants** (implied)
- Most notably used by **Linux kernel**

:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**When you distribute GPL-2 software:**

```text
You must:
✓ Provide source code
✓ Include original license and copyright
✓ Document your changes
✓ License your entire work under GPL-2

You cannot:
✗ Make it proprietary
✗ Sublicense under different terms
```

:::

::::

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 10px; border-radius: 8px; text-align: center; margin-top: 10px; border: 2px solid #ffb86c; color: #f8f8f2;"}
**"Share-alike" requirement ensures software stays open**
:::

## Permissive License Example {.smaller}

**MIT License**

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #bd93f9; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**Key Features:**

- **Minimal restrictions** on use and redistribution
- **Can be used in proprietary** software
- **No source code disclosure** requirement
- Only requires **copyright notice** preservation
- Most popular license on GitHub

:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**What you can do with MIT software:**

```text
Permissions:
✓ Use commercially
✓ Modify as needed
✓ Distribute freely
✓ Sublicense (even as proprietary)
✓ Keep modifications private

Only requirement:
- Include original MIT license text
- Include copyright notice
```

:::

::::

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 10px; border-radius: 8px; text-align: center; margin-top: 10px; border: 2px solid #50fa7b; color: #f8f8f2;"}
**Maximum flexibility for developers and businesses**
:::

# Legal Aspects

## When do licenses matter? {.smaller}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 20px; border-radius: 15px; margin: 15px 0; text-align: center; font-size: 1.1em; border: 2px solid #ffb86c; color: #f8f8f2;"}

License obligations are triggered by **distribution**

:::

**What is distribution?**

- Transferring a copy of software from one legal entity to another
- Providing software binaries or source code to external parties
- **Internal use** within your organization is generally **NOT** distribution

**Examples:**

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**IS distribution:**

- Shipping software to customers
- Publishing container images publicly
- Providing software to contractors
- Selling products containing FOSS

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

**NOT distribution:**

- Using FOSS internally
- Running services on your servers
- SaaS applications (usually)*
- Internal tool deployment

:::

::::

::: {style="font-size: 0.8em; margin-top: 10px; font-style: italic;"}
*Exception: AGPL requires source disclosure for network use
:::

## License compliance matters {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="48%" style="margin-right: 2%;"}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px 0; border: 2px solid #50fa7b; color: #f8f8f2; font-size: 0.85em;"}

**What you need to do:**

- **Track all FOSS** components in your products
- **Understand license obligations** for each component
- **Maintain attribution** (copyright notices, licenses)
- **Provide source code** when required (copyleft licenses)
- **Document your compliance** process

:::

:::

::: {.column width="48%" style="margin-left: 2%;"}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px 0; border: 2px solid #ff5555; color: #f8f8f2; font-size: 0.85em;"}

**Non-compliance consequences:**

- Copyright infringement lawsuits
- Forced source code disclosure
- Injunctions preventing product sales
- Reputational damage
- Financial penalties

:::

:::

::::

# Enterprise Risks

## Common FOSS risks for enterprises {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin-bottom: 15px; border: 2px solid #ffb86c; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**1. Lack of awareness**

- Developers add dependencies unknowingly
- Transitive dependencies go unnoticed
- License obligations misunderstood
- No inventory of FOSS components

:::

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #ff5555; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**2. Security vulnerabilities**

- Outdated packages with known CVEs
- Unpatched critical vulnerabilities
- Supply chain attacks
- Abandoned projects

:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/6195/6195699.png){width="300" fig-alt="Security risk icon"}

:::

::::

## Case Study: Equifax Breach (2017) {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="65%" .fragment}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 12px; border-radius: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; border: 2px solid #ff5555; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**The Incident:**

- **147.9M** Americans + **15.2M** British citizens affected
- One of the largest identity theft breaches

:::

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 12px; border-radius: 10px; border: 2px solid #ffb86c; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**The Cause:**

- **Apache Struts 2 vulnerability** (CVE-2017-5638)
- Patch released **March 6, 2017**
- Breach began **May 12, 2017** (2 months later!)
- Continued undetected for **76 days**

:::

:::

::: {.column width="35%" .fragment}

![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/4401/4401403.png){width="220" fig-alt="Data breach icon"}

::: {style="text-align: center; font-size: 0.85em; font-weight: bold; margin-top: 15px; font-style: italic;"}
Failed to patch a known vulnerability
:::

:::

# Automated Tools

## Why automate FOSS management? {.smaller}

Manual tracking is not scalable:

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px 0; border: 2px solid #8be9fd; color: #f8f8f2;"}

**Modern applications can have:**

- Hundreds or thousands of direct dependencies
- Tens of thousands of transitive dependencies
- Multiple package managers (npm, pip, Maven, etc.)
- Constantly evolving vulnerability landscape

:::

**Automated tools help you:**

- Discover all FOSS components in your codebase
- Identify security vulnerabilities (CVEs)
- Detect license compliance issues
- Generate Software Bill of Materials (SBOM)
- Monitor for new vulnerabilities

## Open Source Tool: Trivy {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}

**[Trivy](https://trivy.dev/)** - Comprehensive security scanner by Aqua Security

- Vulnerability detection
- License scanning
- Secret detection
- SBOM generation

**Scan a container image:**

```bash
trivy image nginx:latest
```

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em; margin-top: 10px; font-style: italic;"}
Free, open-source, widely adopted in CI/CD pipelines
:::

:::

::: {.column width="30%"}

![](media/trivy.png){width="180" fig-alt="Trivy logo"}

:::

::::

## Commercial Tool: Black Duck {.smaller}

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}

**[Black Duck](https://www.blackduck.com/)** by Synopsys - Enterprise-grade SCA platform

- Comprehensive vulnerability management
- License compliance automation
- Supply chain risk assessment
- Policy enforcement

**Configuration (application.properties):**

```properties
blackduck.url=https://blackduck.example.com
blackduck.api.token=${BLACKDUCK_TOKEN}
detect.project.name=MyProject
detect.policy.check.fail.on.severities=BLOCKER,CRITICAL
```

::: {style="font-size: 0.85em; margin-top: 10px; font-style: italic;"}
Enterprise support, extensive database, advanced reporting
:::

:::

::: {.column width="30%"}

![](media/431461.png){width="180" fig-alt="Black Duck logo"}

:::

::::

## Integrating tools into your workflow {.smaller}

::: {style="background-color: #44475a; padding: 15px; border-radius: 10px; margin: 10px 0; font-size: 0.9em; border: 2px solid #50fa7b; color: #f8f8f2;"}

- **Scan early and often** - Integrate into CI/CD pipeline
- **Set clear policies** - Define acceptable risk levels
- **Automate fixes** - Use dependency update tools (Dependabot, Renovate)
- **Monitor continuously** - New vulnerabilities discovered daily
- **Educate developers** - Make security everyone's responsibility

:::
